text: many students have asked me why words

question actually words are spelled
differently in different countries
there's generally two spellings there's
the American spelling and the British

spelling but what usually in textbooks
and what most people see most often is
the American spelling so what are the
differences there are four main
differences the first one is with o
spellings for words like color favorite
armor the British spelling is O Ur while
the American spelling is o o r the
second difference is in E spelling with
words like Center and meter the British
spelling is usually re e borrowed from
French the American spelling is eer the
third difference is with I's endings
like realize or recognize British
spelling spells that eyes sound with an
S American spelling does it with a zed
the fourth main difference is with past
tense verbs with verbs that end with L
like cancelled or traveled in British
English they double the L but in
American English there's only one so to
review the first difference is o r or o
u r the second difference is with e r or
re e the third difference is with eyes s
or Zed and the fourth difference is with
Ed endings with verbs at end an L double
or not those are the four main
differences in British and American
spelling but that brings up another

different what the

way before America was even a country
Britain didn't really have a unified way

pretty popular in the dictionary world
but Noah Webster in 1806 was an American
and at that time in the United States
shortly after the Revolutionary War
America is really looking for a way to
split itself from the European Empire
one of the ways that Webster decided to
do this was through spelling so he
started changing things he claimed that
his goal was simplification removing
extra letters and changing things to be

different kinds of spellings British and

differences o r and O Ur e r and re
e i e and i z e l l d and l d and the
